results.title: The Atlantic community: introducing Norway
results.creator_credit: Bjorn Breigutu, Norsk Dokumentarfilm and North Atlantic Treaty Organization
results.brief_description: Life today in Norway’s arctic country, with its seafaring tradition. Small isolated communities export fish and farm every arable acre even on steep slopes, harvesting during the short summer. Other natural resources include valuable timber and water for hydroelectric power used in many industries. Isolation and a harsh climate tend to make family ties strong. Many men serve in the Home Guard to supplement the strength of the regular troops along this part of NATO’s defence line (of which Norway’s border forms a third).

results.title: The Atlantic community: introducing Luxembourg
results.creator_credit: Ytzen Brusse, North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Ytzen Brusse Productions
results.brief_description: Once a great military power, as its many castles testify, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg is now a highly developed modern society with flourishing industries and agriculture, liberal employment policies and a high standard of living and public education. Luxembourg’s cooperation in the European coal and steel communities and the Benlux group is described in some detail. In 1948 her long period of neutrality was ended by joining NATO, and she is contributing a highly trained combat force, a large airport and an extended road system to the common effort.

results.title: The Atlantic community: introducing Italy
results.creator_credit: Vittorio Gallo, Europa Telefilm and North Atlantic Treaty Organization
results.brief_description: Describes the country and the people of Italy - geographical features, historical development and achievements, economic life, occupations of the people and social customs. Explains briefly the role of Italy in NATO.

results.title: The Atlantic community: introducing Iceland
results.brief_description: Iceland’s chief exports are fish and dairy products, while sheep and wool are produced for home consumption. Steam from geysers provides heating for the glasshouses where the fruit and vegetable supply is grown, and hot water from the same source is piped all over Iceland. The population of 150,000 enjoy a very high standard of living, child welfare and education being especially well provided fro. The film closes with a resume of Iceland’s history and her role as a member of NATO.

results.title: The Astronomers. Eps. 4-6
results.creator_credit: Christine Z Wiser, Linda Feferman and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description: Waves of the future looks at the lives and methods of two theorists as they investigate gravity waves and propose extravagant experiments with gravity wave detectors, both here on earth and in space. “Stardust” looks at the life and death of stars, in particular how they are born in dark areas of the universe. “Prospecting for planets” concentrates on the explosion of discoveries made by the Voyager project, the search for other planetary systems and how planetary systems are formed.

results.title: The Artist, the Peasant = L'artista, Il Contadino
results.creator_credit: Franco Di Chiera and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Artist Giuseppe Mercuri dreamed of emigrating to Australia with his family in the 1950’s but was refused entry on account of his Communist Party membership and only now has he been allowed entry to visit the country of his dreams. His work captures the reflective nature of the people and lifestyle of Calabria, the area in which he was born. In this film his nephew, Franco di Chiera has documented faithfully Mercuri’s life from the hardships of his youth through the years of creative achievement and finally to his long awaited trip to Australia which meant the fulfilment of a lifetime dream.
